segments.text: I wanted to see those things continue and advance uninterrupted.

We were on the verge of really bringing this university to a level of academic statue that it had never had before because we were finally getting to a stage of maturity after the decisions that Dr. Rutter, I mean,
President Rutter had made of the expansion and all that had been put into the university.
And we were beginning to reap a lot of what you and others had done previous to our time.
And I had spent so much time completely redoing the entire undergraduate academic program in focus.
What were some of those major changes?
so many new programs such as the Center for Teaching Excellence.
We had put in a graduate student teaching enhancement program.
We had put in a student advising program from the academic side.
We had put in new strengths into the tenure and promotion criteria so that credit would be given
to our best teachers and that that would be a criteria upon which they would be judged.
We had strengthened the funding to the academic program side at the undergraduate level.
There are probably four or five more that we had put into it, but also along with that,
We had done things to increase the faculty's training in the academic process and in the classroom teaching.
When you look at education, it involves two components.
One is the content and the other is the delivery.
So we were really working hard to look at the delivery and what we could do to enhance it.
Secondly, we had also worked hard on recruiting top students here.
We had gotten
Texas A&M up to third in National Merit Scholars.
We had gone ahead of the University of Texas.
We should just gall them.
And who deserved credit for that?
Well, a lot of that came from the team that we put together in the provost office and all of the associate provosts.
We now had an associate provost for undergraduate studies.
And it was that person's responsibility to work with the academic deans in all the colleges
to really pay attention to what we were doing in expanding our honors courses, our advanced courses.
We then had in that office, an office for honors and, yeah, an office for honors.
Who led that?
Dale Noble?
Dale Noble.
And Dale was superb at getting out in the state and helping us recruit those top-notch students.
And I spent a lot of time traveling with Dale to high schools.
And I spent a lot of time at events he would have here on campus.
We spent a lot of time also recruiting top notch minority students.
And we put in place the outreach centers in the various strategic areas of the state to try to get top notch minority students who were
National Merit Scholars or National Hispanic Scholars, students who were really bright and bring them here.
So we put a lot of time and effort into those kinds of things.
Who was the key coordinator of the minority recruitment?
A lot of that came under Sally Shepherd who was
the Associate Provost for Undergraduate Studies.
Among the deans that you work with, I'm not going to ask the negative, which of the deans would you give the highest marks to in those years?
Well, I was blessed to have some excellent deans and then I was given the opportunity to recruit almost all of the deans.
during my time frame from senior vice president, provost, through my whole time in the president's office.
And clearly, Benton Coconauer in the College of Business.
Dick Ewing is a dean that I recruited that has just done a fantastic job in the College of Science.
There's no question but what Ed Heiler in the College of Agriculture.
John Shattuck did a terrific job for the College of Indian Medicine.
You know, it's hard when you start answering questions like this because you don't want to leave anyone out.
Walter Windler, who is now in the Chancellor's office, did a great job with the College of Architecture.
I recruited the first woman dean ever at A&M.
It was Jane Stallings for the College of Education.
Those deans formed such an incredible team.
One other one that was not a dean's title, but I made it a dean's title, was the dean of libraries.
I should remember her name also.
Fred Heath.
Oh, are you talking about Fred Heath?
Fred Heath.
Oh, yeah.
I recruited Fred Heath.
and felt like that he had the vision to move our library forward because we put a tremendous amount of effort into the current new expanded facilities to get that done and increase the funding.
He certainly is doing a good job.
And to get it technically advanced and Fred had the know-how to get it technically advanced.
On your staff, who were the key people?
Oh, that's easy.
Jeanette Ferris, who to me is, if there's ever been someone that would be termed the institutional memory and know-how of Texas A&M University, it would be Jeanette Ferris.
But she is one.
Jerry Gaston, who was my executive associate provost.
Danny Parker, who was assistant provost for business affairs.
They were absolutely key and crucial.
Where did you find Jerry Gaston?
Jerry was already there.
Oh, okay.
And he was executive associate provost under Don McDonald before I went to that position.
I made a lot of other changes when I was senior vice president provost.
One was to bring the graduate educational programs, the masters and the PhD, and the research to one office.
They were so closely linked, and yet with two different offices there was a lot of wasted money and overhead, and they were unable to bring it together the way it needed.
And I made some tough, hard decisions in that area.
And some people probably in those offices got upset.
But if you don't make those decisions, then you're fostering mediocrity.
So I brought those together into a position that was called Vice President for Research and Associate Provost for Graduate Studies.
Because so much of the time, your research funding
is what funds a lot of your graduate positions.

So we brought all that together and tried to give it a higher level of visibility in the university to give us a greater presence in Austin and particularly a greater presence in Washington, D.C. At a meeting of the deans, we used to call it the academic, the APC.
Academic Programs Council.
If there was a discussion and a difference of opinion, which of the deans with the other deans do you think would have been the most persuasive?
Was there any dean that could move some of his or her colleagues more than the others?
Probably.
for two reasons.

One was that he had a superb program in the College of Business, but secondly, he had also served as an academic vice president and provost at another institution and had a background that was recognized among the others and his people skills did a lot.
And did you have a person that you would have listened to most closely for truly candid advice?
Yeah, I had two people really, and that would be Jerry Gaston and Danny Parker, because we were all just side by side in the provost office.
And Bill Perry, I have to also add Bill Perry.
associate provost and dean of faculties, and I brought Bill into that position.
And I had forgotten him a moment ago as such an important part of that team of people.
So when we had decisions that needed to be made, we were right there in my office, and those were my confidants, and they were people I really trusted.
Now, Bill replaced Clint Phillips when Clint retired.
That is correct.
Bill replaced Clint Phillips and had come from the College of Science.
A superb teacher of math.
A superb math teacher.
According to our children.
And still, when he was associate provost and dean of faculties, he said, I will do it if you will still let me teach one course a semester.
And I said, Bill, I would want you to do that.
I did that every semester of my whole life.
First of all, it keeps you in contact with the realities.
No question.
Absolutely.
Let's see.
Any funny moments you can remember?
Goofy?
Hilarious?
Something came apart?
Well, one of the funniest was the incident I told about the gas, running out of gas.
And oh, I'll tell you one that was.
I had my 50th birthday when I was senior vice president and provost.
And I came into work that day and they had black balloons and things all over the administration building in that beautiful rotunda.
And I thought, well, that's the end of it.
And that was a Friday.
The next day at the football game, we're up in the president's box.
And at halftime, I look up, and here comes the airplane.
Oh, my goodness.
And the airplane has this big trailer on it, and it says, EDG is old.
Happy 50th birthday.
And about that time, they all started looking at it, and they all brought out these whistles and balloons and everything.
And we had a party in the president's box, and it was a great, great time.
Okay, now let's go back to when you became the, and the title was interim?
Interim president.
Was there any surprise that Bill Mobley was selected as chancellor?
No, I don't think so at all because Bill had done such a superb job
in leading the university to a new level of achievement.
And secondly, he had also served as the executive vice chancellor second in command of the system.
So he had clearly proven himself.
All right.
And did, as you became the interim president, is that the word?
Were there any problems created for you by the manner in which you were identified?
Yes.
For me.
A comment or two.
And that created some awkward moments.
And I went to the faculty senate and felt that I needed to explain why I had accepted it, because it was out of my loyalty to continue to move the university forward.
But I was placed in a very awkward situation at that time, no question.
And this occurred, this transfer took place when?
It took place in August of 1993.
August of 93.
And you were still living in your home.
Right.
So there was no discussion of your moving to the President's home at that point.
There was, and we were allowed to if we wanted to, but my wife and I determined that
We might not, if I were a candidate, want the position, and if I were a candidate, I didn't want to give a presumptuous impression.
Although we did stay there some, and we did use the home quite frequently for many kinds of entertaining events.
So you became the CEO of the campus just in time for football season.
Just in time for football season, which I must tell you was my favorite time of the year.
describe how that way.
Well, I'm a huge football fan.
And I will tell you that it was not the regular routine football season.
Because during the whole fall, we were trying to wrap up the entire NCAA investigation of that last infraction issue.
And I spent hours upon hours with
in meetings with university people, with investigators.
We hired a firm out of Kansas City that had a track record of getting to the bottom of all of these.
I know them well.
That's their specialty.
I know them well.
The whole time I was going through football season and going to the football games, I was still handling those issues on a daily basis.
But football weekends were, to me, very special.
Describe a typical home game football weekend.
A home football weekend started Friday.
And it started mid-morning Friday with a lot of events, people coming to town that wanted to see you.
A lot of things were sponsored by the Association of Former Students.
There were usually meetings that they had.
Every college had development council meetings.
All kinds of meetings on Fridays.
So Fridays were just devoted to meetings and speeches.
And I usually just pretty well in advance knew that.
Saturdays of the football weekends were just crammed full and started usually with an early morning breakfast.

What we had to do in order to get from place to place was very carefully scheduling in our office, but we had a student in a university vehicle that would actually drive me from place to place so that I could meet the time frames of where I needed to be.
And it was not uncommon to have and go to six or eight events

And one of the highlights to me was the pre-game meal where I got to thank the people who were there, introduce the legislators, the guests, the board of regents, the other university's president who was there, and to have a little presentation done by a student about some student program at A&M.
And then the ball game and then after the ball game, I probably spent more time in the Hilton without spending the night there than anybody because all the class reunions.
And I might speak to four or five of those in one afternoon or one evening and get home about midnight that night.
But I will tell you that I enjoyed probably those speeches and that interaction as much as anything I ever did in my life.
And I'll never forget
And I probably shouldn't say that sitting here talking to you.
We beat, I think it was the University of Missouri, 73 to nothing.
And it was the class reunion
for the class of 73, and I told them, I said, I just want you to know that I instructed the team to score 73 points for you, and they did it.
And it was one of those unique opportunities that was there.
So those were hectic weekends, and Sunday after a football game was a day of recovery.
Give an example of a goofy request,
proposal that somebody gave to you while you were in that CEO job.
Remember anything?
Well, I'll tell you one of the funniest things that ever happened and one of the goofiest requests we ever got was this written letter

from this dear elderly lady, and you could tell it from her handwriting, who had watched, I think, that same ball game where we scored 73 points, and she instructed me to have the students stop kissing their dates with French kisses after every touchdown, that she had watched it on television, and it was repugnant for her to have to watch, and that I needed to tell the students to quit doing that.

let's see, proud moments well there were a number of proud moments and those would clearly be related to what I would feel would be landmark achievements one was the work done to get the finality of the Bush Presidential Library and particularly the facilities I'll never forget

the humility of the Bush family, and how when we were in Houston meeting with the architects and called him up one Sunday afternoon when he was still president, he instructed the architect that he did not want that facility to be an edifice to George Bush, but he wanted the architecture and the facility to reflect Texas A&M University.
We later had to go back and convince him to upgrade the finish to truly make it look like a presidential library.
But a part of that was a great... Do you remember how you all heard the decision that it would be here?
Yes.
It happened earlier when I was senior vice president and provost.
I believe that we were in a Board of Regents meeting.
when we got the final word that it was going to be here.
And of course, many people had a great part in that.
A lot of board members.
Was it a telephone message?
I think probably it was a telephone message to a couple of the board members who had been very instrumental, and to Dr. Atkinson.
And it was announced, and of course you can imagine the joy that swept through this entire campus and our university.
Oh my, yes.
an achievement that I would be very proud of would be Reed Arena.
We had been stymied and stopped at every avenue to get that facility completed.
The coordinating board was against it and it had gotten out of size.
Some of our board members actually wanted it to be larger than the Super Drum in Austin and that's what
got a jaundiced view of it by the state.
So we knew that we were going to have to cut it back and the board agreed with that.

So we finally got it cut back and internally we were ready to go, but we could never get back over the hurdle of what had happened in the governor's office at that time and with the coordinating board.
And I actually had a board member or two and some in the university that had started putting together a proposal

to renovate G. Raleigh-White and I must admit I became pretty upset about that because that would not solve a long-term solution and we would gain no seats and we'd still have an old antiquated facility.
So we were on Texas Southern University's campus making a presentation to the Coordinating Board when the chairman of their committee that approved new construction

dr santos a physician from lubbock was there and this presentation we were making was about the bush presidential library well they were supportive and all that went well and at the end of the meeting dr santos turned to me and he said well mr president what are you going to do about your special events center
And I told him, I said, well, sir, we need it badly, and we'd love to come to you and you give us approval where we could go.
We've got the funding.
And I said, there are some that are wanting, since we can't get approval, to renovate G. Raleigh White.
He said, well, I can't support that.
He said, you deserve it.
A&M deserves it.
He said, you know, if you did that to G. Raleigh White, that would remind me of something.
He said, you know, you can put a silver saddle on a jackass, but he still looks like a jackass.
And he said, that won't work.
He said, you guys put your proposal together and come see us.
Did he say that in a public session?
Oh, yes.
It was a public session.
Now, it was mostly just people who were from universities making a presentation.
So we went to see him, and he agreed to it.
From then on, it was...
approved all the way through.
The other major achievement was moving Texas A&M from the Southwest Conference to the Big 12.
And that was an exciting time.
Describe all that you can.
Well, I will describe almost all of it that I can.
I want everyone to know that we held out
to the very end, we being the presidents of all of the Southwest Conference schools, we held out to the very end that all of the Southwest Conference schools would go, all eight.
But it became very evident early that the new Big Eight, I mean, I'm sorry, the new Big 12, the other schools, would not accept
the University of Houston, Rice, SMU, and TCU.

And the reason they wouldn't was the fact that their attendance was so low that it would drag down the whole conference and it would drag down the television packages and revenue stream that had to be put together for survival of the larger programs.
We would have been left out if we had stayed in the Southwest Conference, we being the big schools.
And we could never have negotiated the kinds of television contracts that unfortunately are essential to survive in today's big university athletics.
So we knew that we had to do something.
Now those four schools, because two or three years earlier, the attempt had been made to make the change, and the legislative bodies stopped it at that time.
But what they did at that time, they put some parameters of achievement in that these other schools that had not been drawing attendance had to achieve, and they hadn't done it and couldn't do it.
So it was then a time where it could now happen.
And we had meetings all across the state.

The last one that I recall was in Dallas across from the airport where we finally determined that the other four universities probably were not going to be able to follow us to join what was at the time I guess the Big Eight.
There were discussions occurring outside
such as the University of Texas was leaning toward wanting to go to the Pac-10 so that they could be in with Stanford and UCLA.
Well, we didn't want any part of that, and we didn't think that probably that would get a very favorable response from the state legislature.
I had a board member or two wanting to take A&M to the Southeastern Conference.
Well, we did not want to go to the Southeastern Conference for two reasons.
One was their academic statue was nowhere near the schools in the Big Eight.
And secondly, they had more NCAA problems than any of the other schools.
And it was already huge.
So the
presidents began to talk to the chairman, who was the president of the University of Colorado, to finalize how the four schools would go then to what is now the Big 12.
Well, A&M and Texas were still the two big dogs, more than Texas Tech and Baylor.
And there was a little hesitancy to accept them.
And since UT was talking

to pack 10, the chancellor and I were at Scott and White and Temple one afternoon, and we get a call from Lieutenant Governor Bob Bullock, and Mr. Bullock says, I want you in my office at 4 o'clock this afternoon.
So when Mr. Bullock called, he went to Austin.
So we wrapped up our meeting, and we drove to Austin as fast as we could, and it was a driving thunder rainstorm I'll never forget.
And it rained and thundered and stormed the whole time we were in his office.
And I walk into his office, and here's Mr. Bullock.
Here is John Monford, who was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a Texas Tech grad, and from Lubbock.
And here was David Sibley, senator from Waco, and ties, of course, clearly to Baylor.
And here was one of my board members, Board of Regents
And Mr. Bullock says, I want you to know that everything is still moving.
And that I've heard you are all going to the Big 12, A&M and Texas.
And I clearly want you to confirm to these other two schools that you're not going somewhere else and leave them out.
And I want you to confirm that you'll support them for entry into the Big 12.
And he also got the chairman of the board on the phone and asked him what the position was.
Chairman of the A&M board.
Chairman of the A&M board.
And then he got Bill Cunningham on the phone.
And he said, Bill, you guys are not going to Pac-10, are you?
And he said, no, sir.
We're all going to go as the last four schools here at the Southwest Conference to what will be the new Big 12.
And he said, well, I want you to come over here.
And I want you to be in the room and tell these guys this.
So, you know, he was just cementing what we had worked for a good while to pull together that we would then form the new conference.
